item.description:
@skdh @WKCosmo The decoherence-is-enough response would be that it is converted into a classically indeterminate state — I.e., it really is up or down, you just don’t know which. (nb. I don’t really buy this and may be mischaracterising it.)

@skdh @WKCosmo I guess you then need an epistemic/Bayesian updating step to non-mysteriously convert (not “collapse”) your description of the state to the actual observed case.

item.description:
@WKCosmo @skdh “Everything is quantum mechanical, all of the time” is a good slogan, but what does it mean? Decoherence drives systems to near classicality, but off-diagonal terms in the density matrix are still non-zero.

@WKCosmo @skdh But they aren’t zero, so why isn’t the burden on you to show why that has no observational consequences? Or you have just re-invented many-worlds branches.

@WKCosmo @skdh What’s “it”? What is the prediction?
